column4: sudo dpkg-reconfigure gdm immediatley gave another bash prompt but i reboot -h anyway. it did not fix the problem
i'm logged into a tty right now with the same password
should i be trying to reconfigure something other than gdm since i use xfce?
did you do anything to precipitate this?.. install graphics drivers, or whatever?
would have been helpful if you mentioned using gdm
will i try the same with xfce instead of gdm?
probably, but i'm not 100%
if  you were me you would tho, right? :)
if i were you, i'd have told people i was using xfce from the beginning
that ship has sailed, my bad
trying it
it says xfce is not installed when i try that
what did you type?
sudo dpkg-reconfigure xfce
thats not gonna do anything, i could have told you that
i thought you said probably when i asked if i should do it a minute ago :)
ah okay
only other thing you could try (at least that i know of) is sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg
so we can't just replace gdm with whatever xfce uses for the reconfigure command
gdm is "Gnome Display Manager"...
okay, and then reboot -h again?
no change. could it be a disk space issue?
i wouldn't think so.
bazhang: fix for my problem is above if you guys are interested.
